instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Fan Spinning for 2 seconds
threads.message:
First thing first,

Water damage on the keyboard. Geen light OK but no boot... I cleaned the keyboard connector and BOOM ! WORKING.

Thought that I was the new Louis Rossman (Biggest mistake ever!) I decided to look under the board the water damage and clean it with alcool. They were corrosion around <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3310</CHIP>.
And guess what ? Still have green light, fan spining for 2 seconds and stop, no boot !

Need some advice to know where to start ...
Sorry for being such a newbe.

Thanks in advance,

Jérémy

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Fan Spinning for 2 seconds
threads.message: Both <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3310</CHIP> have nothing to do with the board booting. I bet one of the SPI termination resistors/traces is corroded or pin 8 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Look up <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and find all the termination resistors and check them and the traces between them.
